A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Does the concept of a/an Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Image of Map to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Image of a Map involves understanding the output of a function from one set to another, specifically identifying all elements in the codomain that are mapped to by at least one element in the domain. This concept is purely set-theoretic and pertains to the behavior of functions between sets.

On the other hand, the concept of a Group involves algebraic structures with specific properties like associativity, the existence of an identity element, and the existence of inverses for every element. These properties are related to operations within the set that define the group structure.

There is no inherent need for the algebraic structure of a group (or any of its specific properties like inverses or identity elements) to define or understand the image of a map. The definition of the image of a map is independent of any algebraic operations that might exist on the elements of the sets involved; it solely depends on the existence of a function and its mapping properties.

Therefore, the concept of a Group is not necessary to define or understand the concept of the Image of a Map.
